text:
Canton builders: 
We at Five North just dropped a new self custodial wallet on <http://devnet.cantonloop.com|devnet.cantonloop.com>. It’s running on devnet and ready for you to tear into.

Break it. Stress it. Try to break it again.
We want your feedback: UX, performance, bugs, ideas.  Hit us with it all.

Let’s make this thing bulletproof together.

This is an effort to provide the community with a simple self custody solution that creates external parties and can be used freely from anyone.

Hit us with it all.

This is awesome, <@U088WG9UYK1> ! :raised_hands:
Love seeing more self‑custody tooling in the Canton ecosystem. We’ll definitely give it a spin, stress test it & share feedback.

Big kudos to the Five North team for pushing this forward :rocket::fire:

text:
<@U06HUQ2M0FP>

You can self onboarding yourself, and will get a wallet where you own the key(the key is store in IndexDb encrypted at rest).

Passkey is used for user auth.

You can receive/send token to this external wallet and it's purely self-custodial (your key your coin).

text: One quirk - password based security of the localkeys doesn’t appear to allow you to show the private key. The React app only ever shows me the page I’m on when I click to see Private Key. I never see the Private Key value.

elements.text: One quirk - password based security of the localkeys doesn’t appear to allow you to show the private key. The React app only ever shows me the page I’m on when I click to see Private Key. I never see the Private Key value.

text: Otherwise, if I understand your system you store the key locally in IndexDB based on encryption using either a password or a value that is returned via WebAuthN and the associated passkey

elements.text: Otherwise, if I understand your system you store the key locally in IndexDB based on encryption using either a password or a value that is returned via WebAuthN and the associated passkey

text:
>  password based security of the localkeys doesn’t appear to allow you to show the private key.
This is odd. You can definetely view and export the private key out (So that you can import into another browserr foe example).

When you click on "Private key" it will prompted for your Passkey (maybe there is some oddness there if the pass key is manage with password manager and the UX maynot quite intuitive.

But you should be able to export it out (and re-import into another browser).

> if I understand your system you store the key locally in IndexDB based on encryption
Yes, that's correct. If you view IndexDb you will see our data inside a table `5N_Wallet/wallet_store`

But you should be able to export it out (and re-import into another browser).

Yes, that's correct. If you view IndexDb you will see our data inside a table
5N_Wallet/wallet_store

text:
Very cool <@U08987JD1J9>!
UX so far is very intuitive and slick
When you ask me to confirm that I’ve backed up the private key:
1. I’d make the message much scarier to ensure the user understands that losing this backup can result in permanent loss of funds
2. I’d recommend adding a next step asking the user to paste the recovery info back into the web page (to ensure they did it), or to click yet another big scary button that confirms they understand the implication of not backing it up

elements.text: Very cool

!
UX so far is very intuitive and slick
When you ask me to confirm that I’ve backed up the private key:
I’d make the message much scarier to ensure the user understands that losing this backup can result in permanent loss of funds

I’d recommend adding a next step asking the user to paste the recovery info back into the web page (to ensure they did it), or to click yet another big scary button that confirms they understand the implication of not backing it up

text: It seems the “party ID” is fixed :+1:. I can send to a preapproved party ID now. However, the network fee shown is not correct. For 900 CC transfer, in the UI it was shown <tel:19521233100|1.9521233100>. The actual fee is *9 (1% of 900) + 0.6 (receiver utxo) + 0.6 (sender change utxo) + holding fee specific to my wallet,* as it is observed from scan. It may be due to the fee calculation in the wallet is not correct.

elements.text: It seems the “party ID” is fixed
. I can send to a preapproved party ID now. However, the network fee shown is not correct. For 900 CC transfer, in the UI it was shown
. The actual fee is
9 (1% of 900) + 0.6 (receiver utxo) + 0.6 (sender change utxo) + holding fee specific to my wallet,
as it is observed from scan. It may be due to the fee calculation in the wallet is not correct.
